image.altText: A woman holds a black dog overlooking the beach.

props.synopsis: To understand why 30-somethings feel like they're struggling financially, the ABC analysed five factors — housing, healthcare, debt, tax, and income. The data reveals this generation is caught in an economic perfect storm.

title.children: We compared the finances of 30-year-olds now, to 30-year-olds 30 years ago

image.altText: A basketball player speaks to media off camera.

props.synopsis: Jack McVeigh's phone has "pretty much been on silent and chucked under my bed" in the wake of the overwhelming reaction to his phenomenal winning shot to catapult the Tasmania JackJumpers to a chance at NBL glory — and tonight, he is hoping to go one better, with a win for the ages.

title.children: Tasmanians daring to dream as JackJumpers on brink of basketball history

image.altText: A concept design for an AFL stadium at Macquarie Point.

props.synopsis: Labor stalwarts and unions believe Tasmanian Labor needs to rethink its stance on the proposed Hobart AFL stadium following its election loss, with one commentator saying confusion over its policy contributed to defeat.

title.children: With 170,000 foundation members for Tasmania's AFL team, does Labor need to change its stadium position?

image.altText: A group of people holding boxes on their shoulders walk through a green jungle.

props.synopsis: A Tasmanian charity is preparing to freight a shipping container filled with 850 boxes of textbooks and library books to school students in need in the Pacific.

title.children: Donated Tasmanian schoolbooks travel by barge, carried by hand on jungle tracks to reach PNG children

image.altText: A woman stands near the window.

props.synopsis: Small towns across Italy are selling homes for just 1 euro to survive terminal population decline. Foreign Correspondent travelled to Sicily to see what life's really like after you buy one.

title.children: Krastina bought a 1 euro house in Sicily while on holiday. Here’s how ‘the dream’ met reality

image.altText: A family poses for a photograph at a 17th birthday party. Parents have their arms around their two sons, and two grandchildren

props.synopsis: A family of seven that fled Iran 12 years ago fear they could be forced to return if the government succeeds in passing tough new deportation laws.

title.children: The Khasri family fled Iran 12 years ago. They're 'terrified' they could be forced to return under the government's new proposal

image.altText: Ice on a curved globe

props.synopsis: Melting ice in Greenland and Antarctica is changing Earth's spin, which may help experts with a tricky international timekeeping dilemma, a new study suggests.

title.children: Melting ice caps are slowing Earth's spin. Here's why that's messing with time

image.altText: Several rows of solar panels with a wind turbine in the background.

props.synopsis: One in three Australian households have solar panels, but only 1 per cent are made here. A new federal government program hopes to change that.

title.children: Anthony Albanese promises $1 billion to launch Australia solar panel production

image.altText: An image of a very large cargo ship with a collapsed bridge sitting over its stern. Some parts of the bridge are submerged.

props.synopsis: The bodies of two men, a 35-year-old and a 26-year-old, were recovered from a pick-up truck submerged under the mid-section of a collapsed Baltimore bridge.

title.children: Two bodies pulled from river as Baltimore bridge collapse moves from recovery to 'salvage operation'

image.altText: An aerial view of a steel truss bridge that has fallen on top of a container ship in a river.

props.synopsis: The chequered record of the ship's owner in the Baltimore bridge tragedy offers a glimpse of the "murky world" of tax havens and worker exploitation in global shipping.

title.children: Tax havens and worker exploitation behind shipping company in Baltimore disaster

image.altText: Brisbane airport. Plane coming into landing. Virgin

props.synopsis: The National Anti-Corruption Commission has landed its first blow, with a former employee of the Western Sydney Airport charged with allegedly asking for a $200,000 bribe.

title.children: National corruption watchdog claims first scalp over alleged airport bribe solicitation

image.altText: Fiji's prime minister is shown wearing a grey suit and red and green striped tie.

props.synopsis: Fiji's prime minister speaks with the ABC about the relationship between China and the Pacific nation as Beijing's role in the country comes under intense scrutiny.

title.children: Fiji's PM kicks out Chinese police amid concerns over growing presence in region

image.altText: A middle-aged white woman and her adult son, who lives with intellectual disability sitting inside

props.synopsis: As legislation is introduced to parliament as part of a first step towards NDIS reform, the disability community is split about a major recommendation from a recent review of the scheme.

title.children: It might sound uncontroversial — but this NDIS reform is splitting the community

image.altText: Australian Defence Force chief Angus Campbell at the Royal Commission into Defence and Veteran Suicide black behind him

props.synopsis: General Angus Campbell said the courage of those who have come forward to share experiences with the commission was "deeply admirable".

title.children: Defence chief makes unreserved apology for 'deficiencies' in support for veterans

image.altText: Queen Camilla smiles as she greets two women.

props.synopsis: The late Queen Elizabeth II could have had no idea quite how central Queen Camilla would become barely a year into the reign of Charles III — not just to her son, but to the United Kingdom.

title.children: From giving the King's speech to handing out Maundy Money this is how Camilla is stepping up

image.altText: man in suit and tie behind a church lecturn

props.synopsis: In a letter penned to the prime minister by Australia's religious leaders, Anthony Albanese is warned dealing with the Greens on religious discrimination laws would be an "act of betrayal".

title.children: Faith groups warn Albanese a deal with Greens on religious discrimination would be an 'act of betrayal'

image.altText: A man speaks into a microphone on a foreign television channel.

props.synopsis: Australian officials have labelled the Russian election an "insult to democracy", but Port Hedland's Adrian McRae was full of praise for Mr Putin.

title.children: WA councillor praises Putin's 'transparent and comprehensive' election win during appearance on Russian TV

image.altText: A generic photo of ASX board.

props.synopsis: The supermarket giant says it is protecting itself from the potential collapse of money provider, Armaguard. Meanwhile, the ASX has breached new territory. Follow the day's events and insights as they happen with our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Coles hoarding cash instore over Armaguard fears, while Australian shares set to rise

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Aussie gold miner backs away from takeover talks with Canadian outfit
Conditions to cut New Zealand cash rate becoming more apparent

image.altText: Katrina Gorry

props.synopsis: With Sam Kerr already on the sidelines, the Matildas face the prospect of losing two other stars for the Olympics, including fan favourite Katrina Gorry.

title.children: Matildas injury woes continue as fan favourite Gorry faces race against time for Olympics

image.altText: Rick SBS Alone Australia (landscape)

props.synopsis: The survivalists return to once again test their skills against the unforgiving elements in the second season of Alone Australia.

title.children: 'Don't get sooky and tap out': Aussies get dropped in the Kiwi wilderness for season two of Alone

image.altText: Close up of Jessica Mauboy's concerned, slightly ashed face, sandwhiched between a firefighter helment and suit.

props.synopsis: Bullies, bushfires and old sneakers stand in the way of Percy Boy's dream of winning a sports carnival sprint in this feel-good film.

title.children: Jessica Mauboy leads the support cast of this kids movie, but the young star steals the show

image.altText: Imaging shows the SS Lake Illawarra and Tasman Bridge pylons.

props.synopsis: Memories of the fatal event that split Tasmania's capital city in two have been triggered as rescue efforts continue in Baltimore. Maritime workers reflect on lessons learnt from the 1975 tragedy.

title.children: Reminders of Australia's own bridge catastrophe still sit on Hobart's riverbed

image.altText: The logo for Meta is printed on a white box floating from the ceiling

props.synopsis: Posts that have been fact-checked and proven false are slipping through Meta's net, a new report alleges. And the tech giant could be in breach of their code of conduct.

title.children: 'Australia and Russia': The missed fact check that sparked a complaint against Facebook's parent company

image.altText: A woman with red hair and a pony tail wearing glasses looks pensive, she is in front of a brick building

props.synopsis: Amid a national shortage of professional Auslan interpreters, particularly in regional areas, experts are calling for greater investment in the workforce.

title.children: Shortage of Auslan interpreters in regional Australia 'could be deadly', says Deaf community advocate

image.altText: A bright gold bar, with two hands in long red gloves, one holding a hammer

props.synopsis: The gold price set new records this month, as investors pile in to the safe haven asset amid central bank uncertainty and ongoing geopolitical instability, with many analysts expecting further gains to come.

title.children: 'Gold thrives on uncertainty', which is why miners and analysts expect it to keep setting record highs

image.altText: a view of a cargo ship destroyed from the front with collapsed metal beams of a bridge on top

props.synopsis: When the container ship MV Dali lost power and slammed into one of the support piers of the Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore, the bridge collapsed in moments. The images are a reminder that safety can't be taken for granted.

title.children: What happened in the Baltimore bridge collapse and what needs to change

image.altText: Plibersek looks serious as she speaks to a camera in a corridor of parliament house.

props.synopsis: After the Productivity Commission declared Australia's overarching water policy document outdated, the federal government has revealed the details of its National Water Initiative overhaul.

title.children: Better climate science, greater First Nations participation flagged in national water policy overhaul

image.altText: People dance to music at the Rabbits Eat Lettuce music festival.

props.synopsis: It's the first time this type of pill testing will be done in Queensland, and a national first for a four-day music festival.

title.children: 'Don't take the brown acid': Pill testers hope to reduce harm at iconic 'bush doof' festival

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair and a dark sweater poses for a photo by a window in a hospital corridor

props.synopsis: For years concussion patients in Australia have struggled to find or afford the care they need to recover. Now Victoria's first public concussion clinic for adults is aiming to fill the gap — and clinicians are already shocked by what they're seeing.

title.children: 'Just rest in a dark room': the 'old-school' medical advice patients still receive for concussion

image.altText: Texts on a mobile phone.

props.synopsis: In response to the proliferation of sweatshop-style online scam centres in South-East Asia, individual volunteers and groups have stepped up — often at great personal risk.

title.children: After becoming victim to a 'pig butchering' scam, Troy decided to join a group fighting back

image.altText: A man embraces his teammates after scoring a try

props.synopsis: The Roosters look ready to take on the NRL's elite after their thumping win over South Sydney, but as they prepare to take on Penrith, can they rediscover the winning qualities the Panthers know so well?

title.children: As the Roosters face the Panthers, they're fighting to learn a truth Penrith knows all too well

image.altText: An image of the Olympic rings outside the IOC's headquarters in Lausanne.

props.synopsis: Members of the IOC Coordination Commission and the Brisbane 2032 Organising Committee held a virtual meeting overnight to discuss Olympic preparations.

title.children: 'Very positive': IOC backs Brisbane 2032 Games preparations amid latest changes to venue plans

image.altText: A large crowd watches King Gizzard play live at Splendour In The Grass 2023.

props.synopsis: The shock cancellation of this year’s Splendour In The Grass music festival may signal the end of the “multi-genre, something for everyone” approach to live music, according to an expert in the field.

title.children: 'It's terrifying': Music industry reacts to Splendour's shock cancellation

image.altText: A man in military attire stands behind a lectern with a soldier standing guard behind him

props.synopsis: Myanmar's ruling military junta claims the backing of rebel groups by foreign powers is ultimately delaying democratic elections in the country.

title.children: Myanmar military junta chief blames 'some powerful nations' for backing rebel groups

image.altText: Andrew Giles stands next to Clare O'Neil at a press conference

props.synopsis: There's a sense of panic that comes with the prime minister's office walking senior government ministers to a press conference. It sends a clear signal: it might not be the prime minister speaking but his office is certainly taking charge.

title.children: Escorted by their boss's staff, ministers left looking like children being marched from the principal's office
